NAME.WIZARD: > /> Please select Group Number assigned to the EOAT. /> /> If you wish to set up a new EOAT, then select New EOAT. If you wish to view or change an existing EOAT, then press Select EOAT Number assigned to the EOAT. /> /> /> /> /> Input a comment to further identify the EOAT. The comment can be up to 29 characters. If you wish to set up new programs (Macros) to control the EOAT, then select New Macros. If you wish to select existing macros, then press Select EOAT Open or Off Macro/Select EOAT Close or On Macro and select the macro you want to use. /> /> /> /> /> Input the Robot Output port numbers that open or close the EOAT. Input the Robot Output port number that opens the EOAT. Input the Robot Output port number that closes the EOAT. Input the Robot Output port numbers that turn on or off the vacuum. Enter the Robot Output port number that turns off the vacuum. Enter the Robot Output port number that turns on the vacuum. /> /> /> X, Y, Z describes the three-dimensional location of the tool center point relative to the center of the faceplate. Input the measurement between the center line of the EOAT and the tool center point in the X direction. Input the measurement between the center line of the EOAT and the Tool Center Point in the Y direction. Input the measurement from the center of the faceplate of the robot to the point on the tool that performs work. /> /> /> > This is the measurement from the center of the faceplate of the robot to the point on the tool that does the work. Measure this distance and enter it here. The Rotation of a position has three components, (W, P, R), which describe the three-dimensional rotation of the position. Input the measurement of W which is the rotation of the EOAT about X. Input the measurement of P which is the rotation of the EOAT about Y. Input the measurement of R which is the rotation of the EOAT about Z. /> /> /> /> /> Measure your EOAT. Input the measurement from the center of the faceplate of the robot to the point on the tool that performs work. If you wish to set up new weights for the EOAT, then select New Weights. If you wish to select existing weights, then please select Weights assigned to the EOAT. /> /> /> /> /> Specify the weight of your EOAT and part. Input the total weight of the EOAT. Input the total weight of the part. Input a comment to further identify the payload. Input a comment to further identify the payload. Setup EOAT Center of Mass and EOAT with Part Center of Mass. Enter the Center of Mass for the EOAT and part. This is the balance point of the empty EOAT. The unit is cm. This is the balance point of the EOAT holding the part. The unit is cm. Enter offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Input the center of mass in the X direction. This is the balance point of the EOAT in the X direction. The unit is cm. Input the center of mass in the X direction. This is the balance point of the EOAT in the Y direction. The unit is cm. Input the center of mass in the X direction. This is the balance point of the EOAT in the Z direction. The unit is cm. Enter offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Input the center of mass in the X direction. This is the "balance point" of the EOAT with part in the X direction. The unit is cm. Input the center of mass in the Y direction. This is the "balance point" of the EOAT with part in the Y direction. The unit is cm. Input the center of mass in the Z direction. This is the "balance point" of the EOAT with part in the Z direction. The unit is cm. Congratulations! Your EOAT Setup is complete. Press NEXT STEP to continue. Please refer MORE INFO below to jog the robot in the EOAT frame you just taught. /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> />
NAME.MENU: Welcome to the End of Arm Tooling (EOAT) setup. In this Guide, you will set up items such as the Tool Center Position, Tool Center of Mass, and I/O signals for the tool attached to the robot.

EOAT Setup Additional Information

EOAT, sometimes called a tool or tooling, is the equipment attatched to your robot that you use to perform work. In this setup you will be specifying details about your kind of tooling, such as EOAT dimensions, angles, and other applicable parameters so that the robot can properly make use of the EOAT. You can return to this setup to change any setting at any time. If you do not want to save your changes, press CANCEL.

Press the button to choose the kind of EOAT or tool you are using.
Use finger type gripper.
Use vacuum type gripper.

Choose the setup method of the tool. You can choose whether you want to enter your EOAT data directly, or use the robot to record the EOAT information.
Input the dimensions of your EOAT directly.
Use the robot to determine the EOAT dimensions.

Choose your EOAT type.
Choose Straight if the point on the EOAT that performs work is centered under the faceplate.
Choose Offset if the point on the EOAT that performs work is off to one side or sticking out from the center of the faceplate.

Choose a method to record the EOAT Frame.
Use the three point method to define the location of the EOAT frame when the values cannot be measured and directly entered.
Use the four point method to define the precise location of the EOAT frame.
Use the six point method to define the location and orientation of the EOAT frame when the values cannot be measured and directly entered. Use XZ when it is easier for you to record a point in the +Z direction.
Use the six point method to define the location and orientation of the EOAT frame when the values cannot be measured and directly entered. Use the XY when it is easier for you to record a point in the +Y direction.
Use the two Point + Z method to set the TCP for robots which can not tilt their EOAT to the XY plane in the world frame (i.e. 4 axes robots).

Teach Method Additional Information

Three Point:
The three approach points must be taught with the tool touching a common point from three different approach directions. The Three Point Method of defining the EOAT frame always places the +Z direction of the frame outward from the faceplate. You cannot use this method to define the EOAT frame for weaving, Thru-Arc Seam Tracking, or touch sensing if you are using ArcTool.

Four Point:
The Four Point Method requires four approach points to be taught with the tool touching a common point from four different approach positions. This method indicates the approach position with maximum TCP error so that the user can correct that position and re-compute the EOAT frame. Adjust and re-teach the approach positions that are slightly off iteratively until the EOAT frame computed is of desired accuracy on the basis of the TCP error feedback. The four point method of defining the EOAT frame always places the +Z direction of the frame outward from the faceplate. You cannot use this method to define the EOAT frame for weaving, Thru-Arc Seam Tracking, or touch sensing if you are using ArcTool.

Six Point(XZ):
The six point method requires three points that define the direction vector for the tool, and three points that define the location of the tool center point.

Six Point(XY):
The six point method requires three points that define the direction vector for the tool, and three points that define the location of the tool center point.

Two Point + Z:
Teach the approach point 1 and 2 with the EOAT touching a certain fixed point from two different approach points. X and Y are calculated from these two approach points. Measure the Z value with a ruler, etc. and input the Z value directly. Also, input the W, P, and R values directly. (However, input 0 to all three values when the direction of the faceplate and the direction of the tool attitude are the same.)
Select Record the First Point to record the current position as the first point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach the First Point Additional Information

Record the First Point:
Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Try to align to tool so that it is parallel to the Z of the WORLD coordinate system. When you have finished, select Record the First Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record the Second Point to record the current position as the second point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach the Second Point Additional Information

Record the Second Point:
Jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Rotate the tool about the Z axis in WORLD 180 degrees but not more than 360 degrees, if possible. Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches the reference point. Select Record the Second Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record the Third Point to record the current position as the third point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach the Third Point Additional Information

Record the Third Point:
Jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Rotate the tool about either the X or Y axis of the WORLD coordinate. Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Select Record the Third Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record the Fourth Point to record the current position as the fourth point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach the Forth Point Additional Information

Record the Forth Point:
Jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Rotate the tool about either the X, Y and/or Z axis of the WORLD coordinate. Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Select Record the Forth Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record Orient Origin Point to record the current position as the orient origin point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach Orient Origin Point Additional Information

Record Orient Origin Point:
To record the orientation of the origin, jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Jog the robot so that the desired tool +Z axis is parallel to the Z axis of the world frame, pointing in the -Z direction. Make sure that the X axis of the tool is parallel to the X axis of the world frame. Using only the X, Y, and Z keys, jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Select Record Orient Origin Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record X Direction Point to record the current position as the X direction point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach X Direction Point Additional Information

Record X Direction Point:
To record the X direction point, jog the robot so that the tool moves in the +X direction at least 250 mm or more. For example, if the X axis of the tool is aligned with the world X axis, jog in the +X direction. Select Record X Direction Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record Z Direction Point to record the current position as the Z direction point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach Z Direction Point Additional Information

Record Z Direction Point:
To record the Z direction point, jog the robot so that the tool moves in the +Z direction at least 250 mm or more. For example, if the Z axis of the tool is aligned with the world Z axis, jog in the +Z direction. Select Record Z Direction Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record Y Direction Point to record the current position as the Y direction point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach Y Direction Point Additional Information

Record Y Direction Point:
To record the Y direction point, the robot so that the tool moves in the +Z direction at least 250 mm or more. For example, if the Z axis of the tool is aligned with the world -Z axis, jog in the -Z direction. Select Record Y Direction Point.

Jog Assist Menu Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.

Please refer MORE INFO below to open and close the gripper.

To return to this Guide, press HOME -> SETUP BASIC -> End of Arm Tool Setup /> /> /> /> />

Please refer MORE INFO below to turn on and off the vacuum.

To return to this Guide, press HOME -> SETUP BASIC -> End of Arm Tool Setup /> /> /> /> />

EOAT Number Additional Information

Active EOAT checkbox is allowed you to set the EOAT Number as the active EOAT frame. You can select only one EOAT frame at a time to be active. You can jog the robot in the active EOAT frame.

Robot I/O

Inputs and Outputs (I/O) are signals exchanged between devices that allow one piece of equipment to send/receive status signals or commands to/from another piece of equipment. The physical connector through which the I/O signal enters/exits a device is often referred to as a port.

Robot I/O consists of input and output signals between the controller and the robot. RO, therefore, refers to Robot Outputs, whereas RI refers to Robot Inputs. These signals are wired from the robot controller to a connector on the robot labeled EE. EE stands for End Effector. End Effector is a term that typically applies to the EOAT. Robot I/O is usually used to control the robot's tooling.

Macro programs will be created to control the EOAT. If your setup uses Digital Outputs instead of Robot Outputs, then you can modify the macro programs in the VERIFY step.

Offsets (XYZ) Additional Information

X is defined by the reference X, Y, Z frame on the end of the faceplate. The X direction extends in the direction indicated by the reference X, Y, Z frame. Y is defined by the reference X, Y, Z frame on the end of the arm. The Y direction extends in the direction indicated by the reference X, Y, Z frame. Z is defined by the reference X, Y, Z frame on the end of the arm. The Z direction extends in the direction indicated by the reference X, Y, Z frame.

Rotations (WPR) Additional Information

The orientation of a position is expressed as three dimensions, (W, P, R) which are measured in degrees of rotation about the X, Y, and Z axes. For example, 0,-90, 0 means that the position is rotated -90 degrees about the Y axis and is not rotated about the X or Z axes.

Weight Additional Information

For proper robot operation it is very important that the robot has an accurate measurement of the weight that it is carrying. Knowing the part weight and the EOAT weight allows optimal robot response whether or not the part is held by the EOAT.

Center of Mass Additional Information

Center of mass has been defined as the point at which the weighted relative position of the distributed mass sums to zero or the point where if a force is appled causes it to move in the direction of force without rotation. In other words center of mass defines the point at which the mass, that the robot is carrying, balances. This information allows the robot to accelerate appropriately during motion.

EOAT Center of Mass Additional Information

EOAT X Center of Mass (cm):
This item is the up and down offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Positive (+) values are up. There are 0.39 inches per centimeter.

EOAT Y Center of Mass (cm):
This item is the side offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Positive (+) values are to the right of the faceplate when viewed from behind the faceplate. There are 0.39 inches per centimeter.

EOAT Z Center of Mass (cm):
This item is the offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Positive (+) values are out from the faceplate. There are 0.39 inches per centimeter.

EOAT with Part Center of Mass Additional Information

EOAT with Part X Center of Mass (cm):
This item is the up and down offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Positive (+) values are up. There are 0.39 inches per centimeter.

EOAT with Part Y Center of Mass (cm):
This item is the side offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Positive (+) values are to the right of the faceplate when viewed from behind the faceplate. There are 0.39 inches per centimeter.

EOAT with Part Z Center of Mass (cm):
This item is the offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Positive (+) values are out from the faceplate. There are 0.39 inches per centimeter.

EOAT Comment Additional Information

Comment is a 29 character note for the EOAT. Comments are optional, and can be a short memo, or a label for the EOAT.

Open Gripper Test

Turn the Teach Pendant (TP) Enable switch to ON. Press and hold the SHIFT key, then select Open Gripper Test. This should open the gripper. If not, select Edit Open Gripper to view and edit the program.

Close Gripper Test

Turn the Teach Pendant (TP) Enable switch to ON. Press and hold the SHIFT key, then select Close Gripper Test. This should close the gripper. If not, select Edit Close Gripper to view and edit the program.

Turn On Vacuum Test

Turn the Teach Pendant (TP) Enable switch to ON. Press and hold the SHIFT key, then select Turn On Vacuum Test. This should turn on the vacuum. If not, select Edit Vacuum On to view and edit the program.

Turn Off Vacuum Test

Turn the Teach Pendant (TP) Enable switch to ON. Press and hold the SHIFT key, then select Turn Off Vacuum Test. This should turn off the vacuum. If not, select Edit Vacuum Off to view and edit the program.

TCP Verification Additional Information

Rotate the tool about the X axis of the TOOL coordinates. If the Tool Center Point (TCP) is correct, it will remain stationary during rotational moves.

Rotate the tool about the Y axis of the TOOL coordinates. If the Tool Center Point (TCP) is correct, it will remain stationary during rotational moves.

Rotate the tool about the Z axis of the TOOL coordinates. If the Tool Center Point (TCP) is correct, it will remain stationary during rotational moves.

NAME.MENU:
Choose a template to create your program.
Select Blank Template to start with an empty program to which you can add instructions.
Comment1"
Comment2"
Comment3"
Comment4"
Comment5"
Comment6"
Comment7"
Comment8"
Comment9"
Comment10"

Program Name

When you create a new program, you must give it a unique program name. The name should be descriptive and it should tell you what the program does. The name can be from one to 36 characters long, must start with a letter, and it must contain no spaces or special characters other than an underscore.

Program Comment

The comment can be up to 16 characters.

Template Programs

Template programs are sample programs that can be used to create your teach pendant program. They contain default instructions that perform typical robot operations. After you choose a template, it will be copied to a new program to which you can modify or add other instructions.

Check which motion groups the program will control. If the program will not contain any motion, then select No Motion.
/>

Group Information

When you create a program, you define which group of axes, or motion group, that the program will control. Motion groups define different groups of axes that can be used for independent pieces of equipment, positioning tables, opening devices, and other axes. Only those groups configured on your robot will be shown. Select which motion group(s) will be controlled by this program. If you do not select a group, you cannot add motion instructions to your program.

Choose the type of program you want to create.
Typical Robot Program creates a program as a .TP (Teach Pendant) program, which can include almost any instruction available in the robot including motion instructions. This is typical for most operations.
Advanced Program creates a .TP program which can be created for specific motion groups or with no motion. Additional types, such as Job (.JB), Process (.PR), Collection (.CO), Macro (.MC), or Condition (.CH) may be available based on controller settings.

Choose the type of program you want to create.
/>
/>
/>
/>
/>
/>

Program Type Information

Note: Your controller may not have all program types available.

TP Program

TP Program creates a .TP program which can be created for specific motion groups or with no motion.

Job

Job creates a .JB program which can be used as the main program. When you run production, you run the job that corresponds to the task you want to perform. The job contains program calls to each of the processes that will be performed during production.

Process

Process creates a .PR program. A process is a program that directs the robot to perform a specific task.

Collection

Collection creates a .CO program which is used to collect programs together to simplify program maintenance.

Macro

Macro creates a .MC program which can include any instructions and function as a typical .TP program. However, macro programs can be set up to be executed in these unique ways:
  • Pressing a Teach Pendant User Key
  • Selecting an item on the MANUAL FCNTS Macros screen
  • Issuing an input signal: DI, RI, UI, and Marker

Condition

Condition creates a .CH program which will monitor events on the controller and perform actions when the events become true. Only the WHEN instruction is available in a condition program.
We perform the tasks for program teaching of a Pick-and-Place program using the following steps. Perform Create a program first.
Create a program is finished. Proceed to Edit the program.
The Pick-and-Place program you created moves the robot as shown below. Next, jog the robot (manually) to set up the four motion points contained in the program.
Jog the robot to the starting point. You will actually move the robot in the following steps.
Turn the Operator Panel Mode Switch to T1.
Turn the Teach Pendant (TP) Enable switch to ON. The red button on the upper right corner is the Emergency Stop button. In case of emergency, press this button to immediately stop the robot.
To select the method to move the robot, press the COORD key several times until WORLD appears on the screen.

The DEADMAN switch is a three-position switch used to ensure safe robot operation. Hold one of the DEADMAN switches on the back of the TP to the second (middle) position while you perform the following operation steps.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the +% or -% key several times until 10% appears.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the RESET key to reset the alarm shown in the status window.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot.
Jog the robot above the pick point.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

/> />

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -Z(J3) key to jog the robot.
Jog the robot to the point to pick up the workpiece.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

/> />

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot.
Jog the robot to the pass point for moving to the place point.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

/> />

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot.
Jog the robot to the point to place the workpiece.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

/> />

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot. Use +Z(J3) to jog above the place point.
Jog the robot away from the place point.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

/> />
Edit the program is finished. Proceed to Execute the program.
The robot motions you have set up so far are contained in the program shown below. Next, execute the Pick-and-Place program from the first line.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the +% or -% key several times until 10% appears.
If the Step LED is lit, hold the DEADMAN switch and press the STEP key to turn off the Step LED. The continuous execution mode will be selected.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the FWD key to execute the program from beginning to end at once. Keep holding the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key during the program execution.
You have completed the Pick-and-Place program. Select FINISH to enter the TP Editor where you can modify the program and touchup the points.

MENELE.text: Turn the TP Enable switch to ON to edit the program.

NAME.WIZARD: > /> /> /> To backup your files press NEXT STEP. /> /> />
> /> /> To restore your files press NEXT STEP.

NAME.MENU: Select backup device. If no device appears, insert valid USB stick or Memory Card, then select "Refresh Device List". /> /> /> /> /> /> />

Backup Device Additional Information

Front Panel USB (UD1)

This port is on the front panel of most controllers.

Memory Card (MC)

You need to open the cabinet to access this device slot.

Teach Pendant USB (UT1)

This port is located on the side of the TP.

Select the type of backup you wish to perform.
/>
/>
/>
/>

Backup Type Additional Information

System Backup

This will backup all the files necessary to restore the system to the current state.

Image Backup

Perform an Image backup.

Full System Backup

This will backup all the files necessary to restore the system to the current state with readable (ASCII) files.

This is equivelent to performing a MD:\*.* copy.

Full System and Image Backup

This will perform a System Backup with Text Files (MD:\*.* copy) in a date/time stamped "MD" folder, followed by an Image Backup in a date/time stamped "IMG" folder.

NAME.MENU:
/> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> Select your geographic region. Americas Europe Asia Pacific Select the level of Network Accessibility that you want. All network access is disabled. The system will get its setup from the network router.

Security Information

The robot controller is designed to be open and accessible. Robots should be protected by a Firewall to avoid any unauthorized access. The robot is not intended to be connected directly to a public network. Use care in providing any external access to the robot controller.

The accessibility settings here allow you to provide a certain level of accessibility to prevent inadvertent access to Web Services, KCL Access and FTP Write. These settings should be made based on your particular environment. Network is not set up. You must select Set Up Network in order to proceed to the next step. /> Your network has been set up. Select Change Network Settings to modify network setup. />

Network Setup Additional Information

Setting up the network allows you to access the robot from an external device like a PC or tablet. After you set it up, your robot will connect to the network. You must set up your network to continue. If you do not have a network set up at your facility, press PREV STEP and select No Network Access to skip this step. > /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> > /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> > /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> Press NEXT STEP or press FINISH to proceed. For novice users, this continues step-by-step robot setup assistance. Even for expert users, this is an easy way to complete required settings. If you are an expert user and already know how to set up your robot, this exits step-by-step assistance.

Welcome to

Guided Setup

A step-by-step guide to setting up your robot using FANUC's intuitive setup Guides.

Press NEXT STEP to begin or MORE INFO for more information.

Select the alarm at the top of the screen for more information on the active alarm. />

Please review all applicable safety documentation for your system before you continue.

For more information, press MORE INFO below.

Press NEXT STEP and proceed when you understand the safety considerations.

Safety Information

The owner or user should consult the standards for robots, e.g. ISO 10218 and ANSI/RIA R15.06, to ensure compliance with requests for Robotics System design, usability, operation, maintenance, and service.

Additionally, as the owner, employer, or user of a robotic system, it is your responsibility to arrange for the training of the operator of a robot system to recognize and respond to known hazards associated with your robotic system, and to be aware of and follow the recommended operating procedures for your particular application and robot installation.

iHMI Guides Additional Information

  • You can return to iHMI Guides at any time and change any of your answers.
  • Choosing an item on the screen will display the NEXT STEP key.
  • Press NEXT STEP to continue.
  • Press PREV STEP to return to an earlier answer and change it.
  • You can also select a different step in the iHMI Guides by selecting it in the step pane on the left of the screen.
  • Press CANCEL to quit and the Guide will start over from the beginning.
  • Press FINISH when you have completed a setup, and iHMI Guides will record your settings.
Press EXIT to return to iHMI Guides. /> /> /> /> Select editor type. The Touch Panel Editor (Icon Editor) is touch based and easy to use for novice users. This editor requires the touch panel iPendant. Please select the Regular Editor if your iPendant does not have a touch panel. The Regular Rditor is commonly used by experienced users. If your iPendant doesn't have touch panel, please select this editor. If you have never operated a FANUC robot select one of the following for assistance. These are available from the HOME page at any time. /> /> /> />

NAME.WIZARD: > /> /> /> /> This is the name of the controller on the network. Using the digits and . in the keypad, please enter the IP address in the form 192.168.1.100 The subnet mask is typically 255.255.255.0 but might be 255.255.240.0 depending on the subnet size. Ask your system administrator. Please enter with the . using the keypad. This is the router IP Address. Usually it is the same as your IP Address, except that the final digit is a 1. This is required if you are accessing a network outside of your local sub-net. This is the MAC Address of the robot controller. It is not settable by the user. This is the name of the controller on the network. This is the IP address in the form 192.168.1.100 please use the keyboard to enter the address. This is the subnet a mask which is typically 255.255.255.0 but might be 255.255.240.0 depending on the subnet size. Ask your system administrator. Please enter with the . using the keypad. This is the router IP address. Usually it is the same as your IP address except that the final digit is a 1. This is required if you are accessing a network outside of your local sub-net. This is the MAC address of the robot controller. It is not settable by the user This is the name of the controller on the network. This is the IP address in the form 192.168.1.100 please enter with the . using the keypad. This is the subnet a mask which is typically 255.255.255.0 but might be 255.255.240.0 depending on the subnet size. Ask your system administrator. Please enter with the . using the keypad. This is the router IP address. Usually it is the same as your IP address except that the final digit is a 1. This is required if you are accessing a network outside of your local sub-net. This is the MAC address of the robot controller. It is not settable by the user Congratulations! Your Network Setup is complete. Press NEXT STEP to verify that you are connected to the Network. Congratulations! Your Network Setup is complete. Settings will take effect on the next power cycle. > /> /> /> Please verify that you can connect to the robot using this Link on another Network Device. Press MORE INFO if you cannot connect. /> /> /> />

MENU.text: DHCP was not successful consult with your network administrator if the problem persists.

NAME.MENU:
/> /> /> /> /> /> /> Selecting Manual settings will disble DHCP. Continue? EtherNet/IP CIP Safety is enabled on the Robot.
A power-cycle is required to change the robot IP address on this interface. In this Guide, you will set up the Network for one of the Ethernet ports. Press NEXT STEP to start. Select a method to set up the network. The system will receive the network setup from the router. Input the network setup parameters manually.

Network Information

By selecting automatic, the system will search for an IP address from a router or other network service. This IP address is not guaranteed to be the same every time, so consider setting up a static IP address so that the server functions of the robot are always available on the same IP address. This setting is also required for network I/O like EIP or Profinet.

You can still set up and run the robot without setting up the network, but you will not be able to connect to the robot with your Apple, Android or PC device. Select the level of Network Accessibility that you want. Load your own configuration file. Most protocols are disabled. Web server, FTP, and SNPX are accessible. All network capabilities are enabled including external iPendant access. Choose the selected port for your Ethernet connection. Make sure that an active Ethernet cable is plugged into the selected port before proceeding. Port 3 functionality is limited. Press MORE INFO If the Enhanced Vision Ethernet Port option (R825) is installed, then the Vision Ethernet Port (CD38C) Port 3 can also be configured. This port is only available when the option is installed.

Ethernet port #3 supports:

  • Vision Ethernet camera
  • FTP File Transfer Protocol
  • HTTP Web Server
Other protocols including DHCP for automatic configuration are NOT supported.

Connect Information

You should be able to connect to the link information(URL) on this page from your smartphone, tablet or PC.

You can connect to the robot on the local network only. You cannot connect from an outside network or LTE connection. If you are connecting through Wi-Fi, the robot must be on the same network as your Wi-Fi access point.

If you see this icon, there is an error connecting the robot to the network. Try the step again.

If you still cannot connect please check the following:

  • Did you pay attention to notifications on prior steps?
  • Can you connect to other devices on the network with your device?
  • Are you accessing your local Network?
  • Are you using the IP address in the Robot Link as recommended?
  • Did you manually enter a unique IP address?
  • Did you try powering the robot off and on?
If you wish to connect using the robot name contact you network administrator.

This tutorial guides you to jog (manually move) the robot using the teach pendant (TP).

You will learn how to jog the robot in JOINT and in a Cartesian (X, Y, Z) coordinate system. You will learn how to use the key pad on the TP for jog operations.

JOINT will cause an individual joint, or axis, of the robot to move when the associated key is pressed. Cartesian (X, Y, Z) jogging will coordinate the axes of the robot to move the current programmed tool in a straight line.

Overview

This tutorial describes how to jog the robot.
Jogging is manually moving the robot axes by pressing keys on the TP. Manually moving the robot is necessary to position it for programming.
The manner in which the robot moves when the buttons are pressed, will vary depending on which coordinate system you have chosen. You can choose JOINT or one of the Cartesian coordinate systems.
Joint
When TP keys are pressed cooresponding to a particular axis, only that axis will move.
Cartesian (X,Y,Z)
When TP keys are pressed, the current programmed robot tool will move in line with the chosen vector, (X, Y, or Z) corresponding to the chosen Cartesian coordinate system.

The following items affect the way the robot jogs as well as the axes that will move while jogging:
Jog speed - How fast the robot moves when jogging
Coordinate system - The way the robot moves when jogging
Turn the Operator Panel Mode Switch to T1 before you jog the robot.

Mode Switch

The Mode Switch is used to select the most appropriate way to operate the robot, depending on the conditions and situation. The operation modes are AUTO, T1, and T2, although T2 is not available on some robots.
T1 and T2 are test or teach modes, and are used in conjunction with TP use, whereas AUTO is used when the TP is not being used to control the robot. T1 restricts the robot to a safe speed (typically less than 250 mm/sec).
Turn the Teach Pendant (TP) Enable switch to ON.

Teach Pendant Enable

Although the TP enable switch is labeled OFF and ON, it does not remove power from (turn off) or apply power to (turn on) the TP. It does, however, enable the TP to allow certain functions such as jogging the robot.
Press COORD several times until JOINT appears on the screen.

Joint Jog

The COORD button allows the selection of the coordinate system that is to be used for jogging. Joint coordinate system allows you to jog each joint or axis of the robot individually. Therefore, to jog the robot one axis at a time, press COORD until JOINT appears.
Check the override speed to make sure it is 10%. If it is not 10%, press -% or +% (override key) several times until 10% appears.

Override (joint jog)

The override speed restricts the speed at which the robot will move.
When jogging the robot, this speed is a percentage of the maximum jog speed of the robot. When the robot is running a program, this speed is a percentage of the programmed speed.
The maximum value that can be chosen is 100%. The minimum value that can be chosen is VFine (very fine) which moves the robot a very small amount each time a jog button is pressed.
Hold one of the DEADMAN switches on the back of the TP when you reset an alarm and while you jog the robot.

DEADMAN Switch

The DEADMAN switch is an enabling device with three positions. When it is completely released and the TP enable switch is ON, the robot will be in an emergency stop (e-stop) condition. When it is completely pulled in and the TP enable switch is ON, the robot will also be in an e-stop condition. Only when the device is pulled in to the center position and the TP enable switch is ON, will motion be allowed.

Note: When the TP enable switch is OFF, the DEADMAN switch is ignored.

Finally, hold the DEADMAN and press RESET to reset the alarm.
If you cannot reset it, refer to your robot specific documentation.

Alarm Reset

Whenever the robot is faulted, it will not move. Before jogging the robot, any faults must be cleared. If all of the conditions that might lead to a fault have been addressed, simply pushing RESET will clear the residual fault condition.
If a fault condition still exists, the robot will remain faulted even after RESET has been pressed. If this occurs, further investigation is required. Perhaps the problem is something simple such as an e-stop button having been pressed.

While holding the DEADMAN and SHIFT, press either -X(J1) or +X(J1).*

* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Joint Jog (J1)

Joint will allow you to jog individual robot axes in the positive or negative directions.

The jog keys have a dual designation. For example a jog key might have a +X and a (J1) on it. When you are in JOINT, the X can be ignored. You are simply jogging J1 in the positive or negative direction when you press +X(J1) or -X(J1).

For joints J2 to J6, hold the DEADMAN and SHIFT, then press keys related to each joint.*

* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Joint Jog (J2 - J6)

Joint will allow you to jog individual robot axes in the positive or negative directions.

The jog keys have a dual designation. For example a jog key might have a +Y and a (J2) on it. When you are in JOINT, the Y can be ignored. You are simply jogging J2 in the positive or negative direction when you press +Y(J2) or -Y(J2).
To jog in Cartesian, press COORD several times until WORLD appears on the screen.

XYZ Jog

When TP keys are pressed while in an XYZ or Cartesian coordinate system, the current programmed robot tool will move in line with the chosen vector (X, Y, or Z) corresponding to the chosen Cartesian coordinate system.

The WORLD coordinate system (frame) is the default frame of the robot. All XYZ robot positions are ultimately taught in reference to this frame. It is a coordinate system wherein the X vector extends from the robot outwards towards its front, the Y vector points to the left from the robot's perspective, and the Z vector points up from the base.
Press -% or +% (override key) several times until 10% appears.

Override (XYZ Jog)

The override speed restricts the speed at which the robot will move. When jogging the robot, this speed is a percentage of the maximum jog speed of the robot. When the robot is running a program, this speed is a percentage of the programmed speed. The maximum value that can be chosen is 100%. The minimum value that can be chosen is VFine (very fine) which moves the robot a very small amount each time a jog button is pressed.

Hold the DEADMAN and SHIFT, then press -X(J1) or +X(J1).*

* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

X Direction

Pressing the jog key corresponding to the X axis of WORLD frame will cause the current programmed robot tool to move out in front of the robot (away from the robot) or in (toward the robot) depending on whether the + or - key is pressed.

For the Y or Z direction, hold the DEADMAN and SHIFT, then press keys related to each direction.*

* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Y/Z Directions

Pressing the jog key corresponding to the Y axis of WORLD frame will cause the current programmed robot tool to move left or right from the robot's perspective depending on whether the + or - key was pressed.

Pressing the jog key corresponding to the Z axis of WORLD frame will cause the current programmed robot tool to move up or down depending on whether the + or - key was pressed (assuming the robot is mounted on the floor).

Hold the DEADMAN and SHIFT, then press -X(J4) or +X(J4).*

* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Rotation around X

Pressing the rotational jog key corresponding to the X of WORLD frame (key with an arched arrow above the X) will cause the current programmed robot tool to rotate around the X axis of the WORLD frame.

For rotation around Y or Z, hold the DEADMAN and SHIFT, then press keys related to each rotation.*

* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Rotation around Y/Z

Pressing the rotational jog key corresponding to the Y or Z axis of WORLD frame (key with an arched arrow above the Y or Z) will cause the current programmed robot tool to rotate around the Y or Z axis of the WORLD frame.

All steps in the jog tutorial have been completed.

The next tutorial is "Edit a program."

Press HOME -> Tutorial and select the next tutorial.

MENELE.text: Robot will move watch the robot!!

NAME.MENU:
This tutorial guides you to create and edit a program using the teach pendant (TP).*

You will experience the following:
- Program creation using the guide
- Editing the created program

Note: To complete steps in this tutorial, you will need to work in other screens. You can return to this tutorial at any time and continue where you left off by pressing HOME -> Tutorial -> Edit a program.

As an alternative to this tutorial, when creating a new program you could select Pick-and_Place for Beginners. In so doing, you will be led through similar tutorial steps in a special Guide. If you would prefer to leave this tutorial and try this alternative, simply press HOME -> CREATE PROG. and then select Pick-and_Place for Beginners.

*You are required to complete the "Jog a robot" tutorial in advance.
You are going to create a TP program to move the robot as shown below.

About the Program

This program will cause the robot to move from a start position to two positions in front of the robot and then return to a position at or near the starting position. The goal is to learn how to create and edit a program.

This program has four positions:
P[1] is referred to, both in this tutorial and in the program itself, as Home.
P[2] is referred to in this tutorial as the Forward position and in the program itself as Way Point 1.
P[3] is referred to in this tutorial as the Side position and in the program itself as Way Point 2.
P[4] is referred to in this tutorial as the Back position and in the program itself as the END position.
To create a program, you have to work in other screens.

Start the program creation guide by pressing
HOME -> CREATE PROG.

Create Wizard

For this tutorial, you will not create a program from scratch, but rather you will choose a template from a list.
Start by choosing CREATE PROG. from the HOME page.

You are creating a sample program by using a template.
Select a template by pressing Tutorial Program in the template list and pressing NEXT STEP.

Note: If it will not allow you to choose a template, check to make sure that the basic robot setup has been completed.

Template

The robot already has pre-programmed tutorials available for your use. You simply need to choose one from the list.
Among the standard templates is one called Tutorial Program. Choose it for the purposes of this tutorial.

You can enter a program name and comments after checking the template.
Or, to save time, just press NEXT STEP to simply use the default name and comment.

You can select a program type.
Press Program with Motion and then press NEXT STEP.

In the program creation guide, check the summary screen for accuracy, including the template, program name, and comment.
Press FINISH if it looks similar to the figure below.

Program creation has finished.

Once the program is created, the program editor will automatically open enabling you to edit the program.

Of course, pressing HOME will allow you to choose TUTORIAL and then select "Edit a Program" to return to this tutorial.

If you are already in the program editor, as you will be immediately after creating the Template Program, you can edit your program as needed.

If you are not in the program editor, simply press EDIT from any screen to open the editor.

As you make changes, the program being edited is automatically stored each time you make a change.

Program Edit

Since, for this exercise, you did not create a program from scratch, but instead chose a template, you must now modify the program's positions to suit your needs. Entering the program editor simply allows you to modify the template to suit your particular needs.
Jog the robot to an initial position from which the robot program is to start.

Home Position (1)

Since all positions are unique to the robot's environment, the robot does not typically have pre-programmed positions. Therefore, you must create your own positions.

The Template Program, however, does have positions that serve as "placeholders" that you can modify for your use. This position (Home), designated as P[1] in the Template Program, serves as a starting position and should provide clear access to all other program positions.

Place a cursor on the "J P[1]" line.
Hold SHIFT and press TOUCHUP POINT to record the current robot position.

When the position is recorded, the number of P[1] turns from red to black and "@" appears to the left of P[1].

Home Position (2)

Touchup replaces the selected motion instruction's existing positional information with the robot mechanical unit's current position.
Other motion instruction elements, such as speed or the way in which the robot moves, do not change.
Jog the robot forward as shown below.

Move Forward (1)

This is a position out in front of the robot. In the Template Program, it is designated as P[2]. Its exact location is not relevant as we are just trying to program a few robot moves to see how it is done.

Place a cursor on the "L P[2]" line.
Hold SHIFT and press TOUCHUP POINT to record the current robot position.

When the position is recorded, the number of P[2] turns from red to black and "@" appears to the left of P[2].

Move Forward (2)

During this step you will actually be recording the position out in front of the robot. You will be touching it up, meaning that you will record the current robot position without changing anything else about the template position. Its exact location is not relevant as we are just trying to program a few robot moves to see how it is done.

Touchup replaces the selected motion instruction's existing positional information with the robot mechanical unit's current position.
Other motion instruction elements, such as speed or the way in which the robot moves, do not change.

Move to Side (1)

This is a position out in front of the robot, but off to the side of the previous position. In the Template Program, it is designated as P[3]. Its exact location is not relevant as we are just trying to program a few robot moves to see how it is done.

Place a cursor on the "L P[3]" line.
Hold SHIFT and press TOUCHUP POINT to record the current robot position.

When the position is recorded, the number of P[3] turns from red to black and "@" appears to the left of P[3].

Move to Side (2)

Touchup replaces the selected motion instruction's existing positional information with the robot mechanical unit's current position.
Other motion instruction elements, such as speed or the way in which the robot moves, do not change.
Jog the robot back to a location near the home position you have set.

Move Back (1)

This is a position at or near the starting (Home) position. In the Template Program, it is designated as P[4].

Place a cursor on the "L P[4]" line.
Hold SHIFT and press TOUCHUP POINT to record the current robot position.

When the position is recorded, the number of P[4] turns from red to black and "@" appears to the left of P[4].

Move Back (2)

Touchup replaces the selected motion instruction's existing positional information with the robot mechanical unit's current position.
Other motion instruction elements, such as speed or the way in which the robot moves, do not change.
Program editing has finished.

All "Edit a program" steps have been completed.

The next tutorial is "Execute a program."

Press HOME -> TUTORIAL and select the next tutorial.

This tutorial guides you to execute the robot program you have created.*

You will experience the following:
- Single step execution
- Continuous test execution

Note: To complete steps in this tutorial, you will need to work in other screens. You can return to this tutorial at any time and continue where you left off by pressing HOME -> Tutorial -> Execute a program.



*You are required to complete the "Edit a program" tutorial in advance.

Press HOME -> SELECT PROG. to show a program list from which you can choose your program in the next tutorial step.
Or, if it is shown, you can choose the Tutorial Program that you created in the "Edit a program" tutorial from the TEACH row in the HOME screen.

Program Selection

The HOME screen consists of four rows; SETUP, TEACH, RUN, and UTILITY.
The TEACH row will typically show the last program edited as the first item on the left. To the right of that, you are given the choice of SELECT PROG. and CREATE PROG.
As the name indicates, SELECT PROG. allows you to select a program from a list of programs which were already created. CREATE PROG. allows you to create a new program.

If you pressed SELECT PROG. in the previous step, press the button cooresponding to the TUTORIAL program that you created.
The program editor will open and the program will be shown.
Press -% or -% (override key) several times until 10% appears.

Override

The override speed restricts the speed at which the robot will move.
When the robot is running a program, this speed is a percentage of the programmed speed. The maximum value that can be chosen is 100%. Reducing the speed to 10% ensures that you have time to react to stop the robot, in case it does not operate as you anticipate.
Touch the first line of the program or use the arrow keys to select the first line of the program.

Starting Line

When a program is started, it will run starting from the line in the program that is currently selected. It is, therefore, necessary that you put the cursor on the first line in the program, if you would like to run the program from the beginning to the end.

If you position the cursor on a line other than the starting line, the program will start from that line instead. In general it is a good idea to start at line 1 unless you know exactly what you are doing.
Press STEP to turn on the Step status indicator, which indicates that single step execution mode is active.

Single Step

During the testing phase, you want to make sure that each line taught in the program works to your satisfaction. Therefore, before you run the program continuously, you should run it step-by-step. Pressing STEP ensures that every time FWD is pressed, the program progresses by only one line, or step.

In Step mode, each time FWD is pressed, executing a motion instruction, the robot will move and then come to a stop when the destination is reached.

Hold the DEADMAN and SHIFT, then press FWD repeatedly until the last line of the program has executed.*

Note: If the robot does not move as you expect, you can release SHIFT which will cause the robot to stop.

* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Step Execution

Since the Step indicator is lit, every time FWD is pressed the program will progress by only one line, or step. SHIFT must be held in conjunction with FWD to ensure safe operation.

The red box indicates that the robot will move during this step in the tutorial, and therefore caution should be observed.

Your robot will not move if, for some reason, your robot has a fault. You will have to clear the fault before you can move the robot.
After checking that the override is 10%, press STEP to turn off the Step status indicator and start the continuous mode.

Continuous Mode

If the robot performed satisfactorily in step mode, we can now run the robot through the program from beginning to end without stopping at each line. Pressing STEP again will cause the Step indicator to turn off indicating that the robot is no longer in step mode, but instead is in continuous mode.

Note The suggested speed of 10% may be too slow for some users. Athough reducing the speed to 10% ensures that you have time to react to stop the robot in case it does not operate as you anticipate, some users might want to increase the speed slightly. If you choose to raise the speed by pressing +% (override key), be careful! Also note that holding SHIFT while pressing +% causes the speed to increase in large increments. This could result in the robot operating at a higher speed than intended.

Hold the DEADMAN and SHIFT, then press FWD. As long as SHIFT is held, the program will run until the last line has executed.*

Note: If the robot does not move as you expect, releasing SHIFT will cause the robot to stop.

* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Continuous Execution

You are now ready to run in continuous mode. In continuous mode the robot will proceed through the program without stopping until it gets to the end.
SHIFT must be held before FWD is pressed, to ensure safe operation. After FWD is pressed once it can be released, but SHIFT must be held continuously while running the program or the program will stop.

Note: In step mode, each time a motion instruction is executed, the robot will move and then come to a stop when the destination is reached. In continuous mode, however, the program runs continually through each line in the program. Because each motion instruction in the Tutorial Program ends in FINE, the robot will still decelerate and make a very brief stop at each position before proceeding to the next. This deceleration, stopping, and subsequent acceleration might result in a noticeably less "smooth" path than you imagined. Later, you might create a program wherein motion instructions end in CNT instead of FINE. If so, the robot will not necessarily stop at each position. Depending on the number following CNT, at some point in its deceleration before a given position, the robot will "skirt around" the position it is approaching and move on to the next, resulting in a "smoother" path.

All steps within program execution have been completed.

The tutorial is complete.

Press HOME to return to the HOME screen.
